title: Condorcet Reflections on Black Slavery Q3

content.description:
“My Friends,
Although I am not the same color as you, I have always regarded you as my brothers. Nature formed you with the same reason and the same virtues as White people. Reducing a man to slavery and keeping him in servitude steals everything nature has given him.
The justice of nations requires the destruction of slavery. We have shown that this destruction will harm neither commerce nor the wealth of a nation because it would not result in any decrease in agricultural production. We have shown that the master has no right over his slave; that the act of keeping him in servitude is not a property right but a crime; that freeing the slaves is not an act that attacks property, but rather it addresses a crime that should have been punishable by law. The sovereign therefore owes no compensation to the master of slaves.”
Nicolas de Condorcet, French philosopher, Reflections on Black Slavery, essay published in 1781
content.question: Based on the second paragraph, Condorcet would most likely have supported which of the following?

choices.label: Abolition of the slave trade but not slavery itself
Abolition of the monarchy and the establishment of a constitutional government
Reimbursement of plantation owners for the loss of their property
Immediate abolition of slavery as a practice incompatible with universal laws

content.answer: Immediate abolition of slavery as a practice incompatible with universal laws
